content.value_statement: Build professional interactive charts and dashboards with D3.js. This skill provides reusable templates, data transformation utilities, and working examples for common visualization types.
actual_capabilities: Create line charts, bar charts, scatter plots, and pie charts
Build force-directed network graphs and node visualizations
Transform and aggregate data with statistical functions
Add interactive tooltips, animations, and hover effects
Implement responsive SVG charts with zoom and pan
Generate sample data and test visualizations
limitations: Does not include pre-built chart themes or color palettes

use_cases.description: Build dynamic dashboards with multiple synchronized charts and real-time data updates

use_cases.title: Add visualizations to web apps
use_cases.description: Integrate professional D3.js charts into websites with animations and responsive design

use_cases.title: Visualize complex data sets

prompt_templates.title: Simple line chart
prompt_templates.scenario: Create a basic time series chart
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a D3.js line chart showing sales trends over 12 months with labeled axes, grid lines, and a smooth curve. Use sample data with month names on x-axis and dollar values on y-axis.

prompt_templates.title: Grouped bar chart
prompt_templates.prompt: Build a D3.js grouped bar chart comparing product performance across 4 quarters. Include a legend, tooltips on hover, and animated transitions between views.

prompt_templates.title: Network visualization
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a D3.js force-directed network graph with draggable nodes, zoom and pan controls, and color-coded groups. Show connection strength through line thickness.

prompt_templates.title: Responsive dashboard
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a complete D3.js dashboard with a line chart, bar chart, and statistics panel. Include data generation, responsive resizing, and a control panel for toggling chart options.

output_examples.input: Create a bar chart showing quarterly sales data for three products with tooltips and animations
output: Interactive bar chart with grouped layout
Hover tooltips showing product names and values
Smooth animation when switching between grouped and stacked views
Statistics panel showing totals and averages

best_practices: Use the reusable chart pattern with getter/setter methods for customization
Apply the margin convention to ensure proper spacing around charts
Add meaningful tooltips with data values for better user experience
Include axis labels and legends to make charts self-documenting
anti_patterns: Hardcoding data values instead of using configurable data sources
Skipping scale domain and range configuration leading to poor visual mapping
Forgetting to remove previous chart elements before re-rendering
Using too many DOM elements which causes performance issues with large datasets

faq.question: Which browsers support D3.js visualizations?
faq.answer: All modern browsers supporting ES6 and SVG including Chrome, Firefox, Safari, and Edge.

faq.question: What is the maximum data points for smooth performance?
faq.answer: SVG works well for up to 1,000 elements. For larger datasets, consider using Canvas rendering.

faq.question: Can D3 charts integrate with React or Vue?
faq.answer: Yes, D3 works with any framework. Use refs to access DOM elements and let D3 handle the visualization logic.

faq.question: Is user data safe when creating visualizations?
faq.answer: Yes, all processing happens locally in the browser. No data is sent to external servers.

faq.question: Why is my chart not appearing on the page?
faq.answer: Check that D3.js loaded correctly, verify your data binding, and ensure SVG has valid width and height dimensions.

faq.question: How does D3.js compare to Chart.js or Plotly?
faq.answer: D3 offers complete control over every element but has a steeper learning curve. Chart.js is simpler for standard charts, while Plotly excels at scientific plotting.
